Summary: The proposal introduces a hierarchical planning framework for robotics and autonomous systems, combining learned world models with meta-planning to address scalability and interpretability issues. The framework includes a learned world model (VRNN), a hierarchical meta-planner (MCTS), and an online adaptation mechanism. The experiment plan covers validation, evaluation, real-world deployment, and ablation studies.
Strengths: Strong grounding in prior work, with references to recent advances in world models and hierarchical planning.
Detailed and structured proposed method with three distinct components.
Comprehensive experiment plan covering multiple aspects of validation and testing.
Weaknesses: Lacks explicit discussion of potential technical challenges (e.g., training stability of VRNN, computational overhead of MCTS).
Novelty of the hierarchical meta-planner compared to existing hierarchical RL methods could be more clearly delineated.
Limited discussion of risk mitigation strategies for potential failures in real-world deployment.
Questions: What specific techniques will be used to ensure the training stability of the VRNN, especially in high-dimensional latent spaces?
How will the computational overhead of MCTS be managed in real-time applications?
What are the key differences between your hierarchical meta-planner and existing hierarchical RL methods (e.g., Option-Critic, MAXQ)?
What are your contingency plans if the online adaptation mechanism fails to perform as expected?
Limitations: Potential instability in training the VRNN, especially with diverse robotic interaction data.
Computational overhead of MCTS in high-dimensional latent spaces may limit real-time applicability.
Generalization of the world model to entirely novel environments may be challenging.
